info.name: Black Google by Panos - R. Schneider Mod (Large)
info.description:
[My Large Logo user style - - - - Medium Logo user style also available]
FIXED: Panos' style and other derivatives of it have progressive De-Centering of their Google logo with page-zoom change / a large gray box around the search query box / and a white footer-bar on the Search Results page. ALL 3 are fixed in my userstyle. Also, Google logo is larger, more vibrant-colored, with better highlights and 3D effect (Panos' is "washed out"). Detailed "Comments" section at top of CSS demarcates Panos' code from mine, and tutorial shows users how to use their own logo. I also credit Panos for his generally excellent work in my CSS "Comments". I also have a Google favicon mod (a Greasemonkey user script):
    "Revert to Google's Old 2012-2015 Favicon"
    (reverts to the "white lower-case 'g' in a blue square" favicon)... https://greasyfork.org/en/scripts/12271-revert-to-google-s-old-2012-2015-favicon
info.additionalInfo: 2016 Nov 05 - Update: This userstyle, Panos' userstyle, and other derivatives of it have had an issue with the Google Search Results page (not the homepage), having a white footer-bar (the band enclosing the Location callout near the bottom of the Search Results page) - and I've lived with it until now. However, when using another Stylish userstyle simultaneous with mine, the excellent "Google Search Tools Back", I noticed even Google's homepage reverts to a white footer-bar, spoiling the black-Google effect - big time. So I added an element to the black-color over-ride rules in this style's CSS. By adding "#fbar" to the "{background: #000 !important; ...}" elements list, the footer bar stays black - on Google's Search Results page when this style is used alone, and especially on Google's homepage with both this style & "Google Search Tools Back" used simultaneously. The "#fbar" change forces the footer-bar to stay black, no matter what. Panos' style continues to have the white footer-bar issue (on the search results page when his userstyle is used alone - and also on Google's homepage when used simultaneously with certain other userstyles). Until Panos and all other derivitives make the "#fbar" change, they will continue to have the white footer-bar issue. 2016 Oct 28 - UPDATE REQUIRED !! The Google Logos my 2 Userstyles use were unreachable on the internet, so my Userstyles lost my logos, through no fault of mine or the userstyles. I then uploaded my 2 Google logos (for both my Large and Medium Black Google userstyles) to another image hosting service, and edited my userstyles to point to the new logo image hosting URLs on Imgur.com. My 2 Google userstyles were restored, and need manual updating on computers that don't have their Stylish userstyles set to auto-update. The image hosting service I had used for my Google logos, Postimage.org (founded in 2004), was taken offline by their Content Delivery Network provider, CloudFlare - which made the logo portion of my userstyle unreachable (resulting in a totally black area above Google's search query box). That's right, CloudFront shut down Postimage.org's image hosting server access, making nearly 140 million images hosted by Postimage, and embedded into some 450 thousand websites, totally unreachable - due to Postimage exceeding CloudFlare's bandwidth useage limits - even though CloudFlare clearly states, on their Support page, "CloudFlare does not have bandwidth limits ..." Postimage.org's images remained offline for 2 days. Postimage.org posted pleas on their homepage for help to stay alive in the form of donations and CDN services, and 9 days after the problem started, on Nov 5, Postimage.org posted thanks for help received, from both individual users and server and CDN companies. (I uploaded Postimage.org's NOTICE about the problem, and their UPDATE regarding help received, in a PasteBin posting of mine for those interested, at http://pastebin.com/0Dp510C2). [NOTE: CloudFlare.com should not be confused with another CDN with a similar name, Cloudfront.net.] 2016 Mar 07 - THIS UPDATE FIXES Panos code's large gray rectangle surrounding the search box and buttons (also having a thin, off-center black border immediately around the search box), by changing that rectangle from gray to black (therefore eliminating the rectangle), for a uniform black background across the entire screen. (See my 3rd screenshot - linked under my Main screenshot - showing the ACTUAL "Black Google by Panos" style's gray rectangle - its specific gray color IS SPECIFIED in Panos' code. The screenshot Panos has posted for the current style is not currently accurate, and has been false for well over a year; that gray rectangle has been there, but Panos doesn't show it in his screenshot. An old screenshot was probably left in place instead of being updated, but that falsely represents his style's appearance. I finally got fed up with it and eliminated it with this update for a much cleaner appearance). ALSO, a temporary fix for horizontally centering the search box itself on the screen (it's not centered perfectly even on Google's page unmodified, i.e. with User Styles disabled) - this is NOT a Panos code issue, it is a Google code issue that was not dealt with by Panos. The code change I made centers the search box for my screen resolution. A fix for 'responsive design' (with 'fluid width') for all screen resolutions, to perfectly center the search box for all resolutions AND screen magnifications requires further CSS changes which I'm too busy to address now, probably requiring addressing a Child-Element centering within Parent-Element issue. (See the secondary screenshot, linked below the main screenshot), comparing the center details of Panos' style with this one). [NOTE: After installing this user style, if the search box isn't horizontally centered on your screen, you can modify a CSS setting to adjust it on your screen as follows: Firefox Menu "Bookmarks" (or Alt+F "Bookmarks" > "Add-Ons Manager" > "User Styles" > click "Edit" for this Style > in the User Style Editor that opens, scroll down to find line "#sb_ifc0" (approximately line 414) > THEN, on the NEXT line modify the "width" value - change it from "556px" to a lower number of pixels to move search box centering leftward, or a higher number of pixels to move search box centering rightward. THEN CLICK "SAVE" near the upper left. Changes are applied to Google's homepage immediately, if this user style is Enabled. This workaround for my temporary fix will be not be necessary after I implement the permanent fix. (The pixel change instructions are summarized in a Comment Block in the CSS code right above the "#sb_ifc0" line).] 2015 Dec 06 - THIS UPDATE FIXES Panos' style issue of Logo Horizontal Centering, as well as the De-Centering that occurs with changes in page zoom magnification. (Centering with this style is absolutely perfect, regardless of page zoom - more details in "Comments" section at top of CSS code). This style's Google Logo size is 38% wider than my Medium Logo style, and 69% wider than Panos' small logo. If you're like me, and sometimes feel my Large Google Logo version is too bombastic, or my Medium Google Logo version is too demure - install both styles, then simply switch between the 2 at a whim... Click the "S"-in-blue-square' Stylish icon (by default at the lower-left of screen in Add-On Bar/Status Bar, but can be customized into any Firefox toolbar), then click the style(s) to enable or disable. (If one or more user style for a website is installed, but disabled, the Stylish icon is differently colored - "S"-in-gray-square"). In less than 5 seconds you can switch between styles, if more than one is installed per site. No need to enable/disable via Firefox Add-Ons Manager, you do it on any webpage having styles installed, via the Stylish icon. (For example, I have 2 styles from different authors installed for Wikipedia.org, with both enabled - unless I want to save the Wikipedia webpage, then I quickly disable both via the Stylish icon). Panos Licensed his work in the Public Domain (Creative Commons CC0, aka Creative Commons "Zero"), not even requiring attribution. (That means anyone could copy his work and redistribute it, EVEN UNDER A NEW NAME, without ANY attribution). But I fully attribute his fantastic work, and demarcate his style's code from my modifications in a very detailed "COMMENTS" section at the top of the User Style. My derivative style is Licensed as Creative Commons CC BY-NC, allowing free use, modification, and distribution (but only Non-Commercially) - BUT requiring attribution for all authors - from now on Panos will be assured attribution through my style's License terms. (License Terms are at: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/)

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

                    (below the 2-line asterisks separator)

                 			         LEGAL NOTICE

(1) The modifications to the #lga>* code block (differing from Panos' original code) that enabled absolute, perfect logo centering regardless of webpage zoom magnification (stipulated below, in the example "in-code" "commented-out" LEGAL NOTICE TEXT) are Copyright © 2015 by R. Schneider - rschneider@engineer.com, and must be attributed.

(2) All Text Comments, tutorial information, and similar original written material herein that are retained in the user style, or used elsewhere, are Copyright © 2015 by R. Schneider - rschneider@engineer.com, and must be 
attributed.

LEGAL NOTICE: Panos, and all authors of user styles derivative of his "Black Google by Panos", are free to use the #lga>* code block modifications made in this user style in their own similar CSS styles, but ONLY subject to the following legal restriction - Under the License Terms at time of issuance of the "Black Google by Panos - Mod by R. Schneider (Lg)" user style, and its predecessor "Black Google by Panos - Modified by R. Schneider", (specifically Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial /aka CC BY-NC) - ATTRIBUTION must be given, as shown below. That specifically refers to the #lga>* code block changes that enabled, for the first time, absolute, perfect logo centering regardless of webpage zoom magnification; as well as Copyright protection for any and all original Text Comments, tutorial information, etc - that are either retained in the user style, or excerpted and used elsewhere.

[Suggestion: Use an in-code "commented-out" text notice, inserted immediately above the #lga>* code block, such as the following]:

/* LEGAL NOTICE: #lga>* code block changes below are Licensed under CC BY-NC (Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial) AND Copyright © 2015 by R. Schneider - rschneider@engineer.com (author). The following code changes to the #lga>* code block enabled, for the first time, absolute, perfect logo centering regardless of webpage zoom magnification. (With Panos' original code, the logo was only approximtely centered, and it de-centered dramatically, and progessively more, with page zoom). The following changes fixed that issue - ADDING "center" value to "background:url" declaration (it had not been used before); and REMOVAL of 3 declarations from Panos' code ("position:absolute", top:_px", and "left:_%"). The code changes can be freely copied and used AS LONG AS ATTRIBUTION IS MADE by including this LEGAL NOTICE with its attribution, above the #lga>* code block. */
/*

[Panos PLACED his work into the Public Domain - Licensed as CC0 / Creative Commons 0 (zero).
 R. Schneider Licensed his as CC BY-NC, which requires ATTRIBUTION, and Non-Commercial use only.]

   The following were ALL originally published UNDER the "CC BY-NC" License:

              "Black Google by Panos - Modified by R. Schneider"
              "Black Google by Panos - Mod by R. Schneider (Lg)"
              "Black Google by Panos - Mod by R. Schneider (Sm)"

Early copies of these user styles that did not include this LEGAL NOTICE are still bound by its terms, due to their CC BY-NC publication Licenses. This NOTICE is simply an explanation to all users as to the Legal Terms that have existed ever since the styles' were first created - owing to to their CC BY-NC Licenses in effect at the time of first publication.

******************************************************************************

For the "tl;dr" (Too Long; Didn't Read) crowd, let me apolozize. I call it "The Tyranny of Fine Detail" (my quote.) I am a published scientist and engineer, and approach technical subject matter in meticulous detail. That is my only defense for the accusation of being too wordy. However, some of the details I present will be a good tutorial for some newbies or tinkerers who want to modify CSS code, learn new tricks, etc. I've always evangelized for both a "better" web, and a "better looking" web." So those who haven't yet gotten their feet wet in User Styles or User Scripts (such as Greasemonkey, etc), might be inspired to "jump in with both feet". If so, all the better.

******************************************************************************

FIRST, I give great praise to Panos for his excellent work !!!

I've been using Black Google by Panos for well over a year, and even praise it (and link to it) on the Greasyfork.org page for my "Revert to Google's Old 2012-2015 Favicon" Greasemonkey script* (with screenshot of the center logo detail). If you hate the new Google favicon foisted on the world Sept 1, 2015 as much as I do, check out my Geasemonkey script...
 * https://greasyfork.org/en/scripts/12271-revert-to-google-s-old-2012-2015-favicon

On the UserStyles.org page for this Style*, I include a secondary screenshot mashup comparing the Google homepage logo (center details only) with User Style enabled - showing Panos' style at top, and my larger logo style at the bottom, making comparison of the 2 styles easy. That screenshot is linked in "More screenshots" below the main displayed screenshot of this style.
 * https://userstyles.org/styles/121391/black-google-by-panos-mod-by-r-schneider-lg

After posting my original Style as "Black Google by Panos - Modified by R. Schneider", with large logo, I then
    also posted a second style, with a smaller logo (still larger than Panos'), and renamed my original style.
     My 2 styles are:
 * "Black Google by Panos - Mod by R. Schneider (Lg)" - logo size = 476x211 pixels
 * "Black Google by Panos - Mod by R. Schneider (Sm)" - logo size = 345x153 pixels
            [My (Sm) version was originally posted with logo size = 281x125 pixels]
                  The Original, "Black Google by Panos" logo size = 281x103 pixels

All code not mentioned or referred to in this COMMENTS section are Panos'.

***********************************************************************************
***********************************************************************************

                    FIX FOR PANOS' CENTERING/DE-CENTERING ISSUE

The original "Black Google by Panos", which I've used for over a year, has always suffered from a Google logo centering issue. The HORIZONTAL CENTERING IS ONLY APPROXIMATE, AND THE LOGO DRAMATICALLY DE-CENTERS WITH PAGE ZOOM MAGNIFICATION. I posted my first derivative, "Black Google by Panos - Mod by R. Schneider (Lg)", having a much larger logo than Panos'. With Panos' code (even after adjusting Values of his various #lga>* code block Properties), I found great difficulty centering the large logo. Then, I found that by REMOVING 3 lines of Panos' code (Declarations), my large logo automatically centered PERFECTLY, and remained centered REGARDLESS of page zoom - WITHOUT adding or adjusting any "position" Properties or Values. Then I posted my second style, "Black Google by Panos - Mod by R. Schneider (Sm)", having a smaller logo (but larger than Panos'). I found that removing those 3 lines from Panos' code alone DID NOT result in perfect centering for a smaller logo. I then found a universal way to perfectly center a logo regardless of size, by putting an ADDED Value ("center") in the "background:url" Declaration, as long as those 3 problematic code lines were removed.
 [NOTE: CSS speak: a Declaration comprises a Property and a Value, separated by a colon, i.e.,  a Declaration = some Property:some Value]

[If you look at other Google homepage styles on UserStyles.org (especially other dark or black styles), you will see other styles that DON'T EVEN COME CLOSE to being centered, let alone during page zoom - I even tried 2 of them - "My Black Google by Panos", and Black Google Derivative") based on Panos' - before settling on Panos' style for more than a year. Those other styles may have inherited Panos' issue from his code - I didn't examine theirs. After publishing my own styles, however, I wasn't satisfied to accept the problem, and worked for hours to find the fix (it probably should have taken me only 30 minutes or less). It was the fact that there were 3 superfluous lines of code - that could either have their Properties OR Values modified, or entire Declarations deleted - individually, or in combination, that threw me into chaos).]

BOTTOM LINE - 3 lines of Panos' code should be REMOVED (for any logo size), and 1 Declaration needs an ADDED Value. Additionally, 1 Property's Value must be MODIFIED to adjust the logo's vertical position. (Full details are listed in the "TO CHANGE THE VERTICAL POSITION OF THE LOGO" section below, and in the "commented-out" text block in the CSS just above the #lga>* code block (in the mid-800s of code line numbers), and in the in-line "comments" for the 5 code lines in that block that require Value changes or Declaration removals. The 3 lines of Panos' original code that should be removed are left in-place (for historic versioning), BUT ARE "COMMENTED-OUT" (with added text explanation), in my style's code.

[NOTE: Using my code fix as described above DOES result in PERFECT centering of the Google logo (regardless of page zoom magnification) - as measured by a millimeter rule on an actual display monitor. HOWEVER, PANOS' QUERY BOX IS SLIGHTLY OFF CENTER BELOW THE LOGO - it is such a minor distraction that I do not intend to troubleshoot or attempt to fix it at this time. THEREFORE, the horizontal logo position and the query box don't have the same center point, so their relative centering is "off". It is the query box, not the logo, that is "off-center" (shifted right by 3mm on my display - yielding 6mm more distance between left edge of display to query box, than from the right edge of display to query box). There is also a partial black box outline artifact around the top and left side of the query box, shifted up and left. At this time, the minor query box anomalies don't interest me. Be assured though, that the logo centering issue appears to be perfectly resolved.]

***********************************************************************************
***********************************************************************************

                   TO CHANGE THE VERTICAL POSITION OF THE LOGO

ALL USERS NOTE: To suit your personal preference, you can CHANGE THE VERTICAL POSITION OF THE LOGO between the query box and top of the webpage, by changing a number-of-pixels Value in a the CSS. The pixel Value can be changed quickly, and results are seen on the webpage as soon as you click "Save" in the Stylish Code Editor, WITHOUT a webpage refresh. The pixel Value you can experiment with is the "padding:_px!important;" line in the #lga>* code block. (The "_" represents whatever number of pixels is chosen). See the text block in this COMMENTS section labeled...

************  EASY WAY TO FIND the #lga>* code block, and the "CHANGES"" COMMENT TEXT BLOCK ABOVE IT  ************

for details on how to use the Stylish Code Editor to find the #lga>* code block (which has the "padding:_px!important;" line in it).

Increasing the number of pixels pushes the logo further down from the top of the webpage, closer to the query box.
Decreasing the number of pixels does the opposite.

DON'T FORGET TO CLICK "SAVE" IN ORDER TO HAVE YOUR CHANGE IMPLEMENTED, AND TO SEE THE RESULT.

Further info on #lga>* code block modifications are found in a large "commented-out" text block above the "Legal Notice" block.

***********************************************************************************

Since Panos chose a "Public Domain" License - CC0 (Creative Commons 0; "0" = zero), anyone is free to take his work and modify it, and even to redistribute the modified version, without having to attribute his work. However, even though Panos' License doesn't require attribution, I fully acknowledge and credit Panos' hard work, and DO NOT CLAIM IT AS MY OWN. The modifications I made are relatively minor, and documented in detail here. I chose a different License, also from Creative Commons. This work is Licensed as CC BY-NC (Creative Commons Attribution, NonCommercial 4.0 International). This means all prior work MUST be attributed to its author(s), in order to comply with my license, assuring Panos will be getting full credit for his work through this User Style's license (as will I), even though he placed his original work in the Public Domain. (The Creative Commons CC BY-NC 4.0 License Terms are at: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/)

***********************************************************************************

There are 3 errors in Panos' CSS code (3 different lines of code) - reported when the "Check for Errors" button of the Stylish Editor is clicked. All 3 of those errors are labeled "Error in parsing value for 'background' - Declaration dropped". The 3 code lines with Errors reported all involve "webkit" values, so those 3 lines only affect WebKit-based browsers (Google Chrome/Chromium, Apple Safari, Opera) - I use Firefox, but none of the others, so I've never seen any effect. I ran a Ctrl+F search for webkit, and those 3 error lines are the only webkit code lines in Panos' CSS. Since those errors won't affect Firefox-only users (like me), I made no attempt to troubleshoot or fix those 3 "errors" - they remain...

NOTE: I've seen CSS code in another Stylish user style where the Stylish Code Editor flags ALL WebKit declarations as Errors - - could these be Stylish Code Editor "false positive" error detections?

            ********************************

I wanted to modify Panos' style with a different Google logo, having a darker color hue and higher color saturation, and with nice highlighting and shading for a better 3D effect (I think the logo used by Panos looks "washed out", and is too small for me). [See the screenshots comparison mentioned in the 4th paragraph above, "On the UserStyles.org page...".] I think the logo edits I made (darker hue, more color saturation, etc) create a more vibrant image - with more visual "punch". My original modification of Panos' user style used my new logo resized to the same width as Panos', but it was 22 pixels higher. I adjusted Panos' code to properly position my taller logo, and it worked and looked good - but then decided to use a MUCH LARGER version of my logo instead, similar to the size used by the standard Google logo and some of the Google Doodles. My new logo was significantly larger than both Panos' and my first replacement logo. But my style suffered from the same issue that has always affected Panos' style - his logo is only approximately centered, and it dramatically and progressively de-centers when the page is zoom magnified. I troubleshot and fixed that problem - complete details can be found in the "FIX FOR PANOS' CENTERING/DE-CENTERING ISSUE" between the 2-line asterisks separator lines above, and in the "commented-out" text block in the CSS code [demarked ******  CHANGES FOR NEW LOGO (NOTES by R. SCHNEIDER) ******] - search the code for the string "#lga>*" (without quotes) to find the relevant code block, in the mid-800s of code line numbers (search details below)...

I decided to publish a second style with another logo size choice - a second style instead of using a Style Settings drop-down box (which requires the user to choose one style before installation, or accept the default) - because doing so limits the user to only one installed logo size. Publishing the second style enables users to download both styles, and change which of 2 logos to display with a simple click of the Stylish logo (when on Google's homepage), then clicking to enable or disable each of the 2 installed styles. In a split moment, users can change the Google homepage logo size on a whim, IF 2 separate styles are installed. Other than the logo size, both my "...(Lg)" and "...(Sm)" styles are identical - exactly the same CSS is used, EXCEPT for the "lga>*" code block's image URL and "padding:_px" value.

************  EASY WAY TO FIND the #lga>* code block, and the "CHANGES"" COMMENT TEXT BLOCK ABOVE IT  ************

In Firefox Add-ons Manager -> User Styles -> click "Edit" for this style. Once in Stylish's code editor, click the code area of the window to fix focus, press "Ctrl+F" on your keyboard, type in "#lga>*" (without quotes), press "Enter" on keyboard (all found strings are then highlighted), then scroll down past the highlighted strings displayed in this COMMENTS section to the #lga>* block in the CSS code (below the 17 lines of "#hplogo-n," - code lines numbered in the mid-800s). I've included "commented-out" text above the code block detailing the changes that must be made for different logo sizes.

Details about the origin of the graphics for the logo I used, and how any user can substitute their own logo, appear below.

If users want to see my logo in a different size (or use my original small, same-width-as-Panos') logo, I uploaded 4 to PostImage.org (from which this Style pulls 1 of those 4 - more about PostImage.org below) - URLs and pixel sizes are shown below. NOTE: after using a different size logo (either one of mine, or one of your choosing), changes must be made in the #lga>* code block to accommodate size differences - see my "commented-out" section referred to in the 2nd paragraph above for details.

http://s28.postimg.org/46j6k8ma5/gglmrrblk.png - Original 793x352 pixels - used for my graphics editing, plus 3 down-sized versions...
http://s14.postimg.org/w5ldk5k5t/gglmrrblk_476x211.png -  476x211 pixels - USED IN MY "...(Lg)" style
http://s13.postimg.org/ir841wex3/gglmrrblk_345x153.png -  345x153 pixels - USED IN MY "...(Sm)" style (currently posted)
http://s13.postimg.org/jji2zt553/gglmrrblk_281x125.png -  281x125 pixels - USED IN MY "...(Sm)" style (as first posted)
http://i.imgur.com/KAfdVfw.png     (Panos' original)      281x103 pixels - USED IN "BLACK GOOGLE BY PANOS"

One thing I like about Stylish User Styles is that as soon as edit changes are made and "Save" is clicked at the top of the Stylish CSS editor, the affected webpage immediately shows the user style changes WITHOUT requiring a page refresh. This makes it quick and easy to see whether you need to tweak your code changes, or if you made an error.

NOTE: If you use your own logo with different dimensions, or simply don't like the vertical positioning of the logo between the query box and top of page, modifying the "paddig:_px!important;" line in the #lga>* code block can be changed to suit your preference. Further hints are included in the "TO CHANGE THE VERTICAL POSITION OF THE LOGO" section above in these COMMENTS, and in the "CHANGES..." text block "commented-out" above the #lga>* code block discussed in the next paragraph.

[By following my example and the instructions below, any user can substitute their own edited logo - and upload their image to a free image hosting site. PostImage.org is good, free, never deletes due to inactivity (Panos' host site, imgur.com, deletes all images not viewed at least once in a 6-month period), and does NOT require Registration. After the image is uploaded to an image hosting site, specify the image's URL in the CSS code (insert into Panos' code at "background:url" in the code block "#lga>*" - Ctrl+F search this style for the "#lga>*" string, without the quotes) - NOTE: Embedding a base64-encoded image as "CSS Background Source Data" in place of the external "Background URL" is NOT recommended - that could make the modified style CSS TOO LARGE to be hosted on UserStyles.org. (From https://userstyles.org/help/coding: ("Limits on User Styles" section) "Maximum size is 100,000 bytes. Exemptions are possible by contacting me <link to admin Jason Barnabe's email>, I won't grant exemptions if you're using embedded images"). Jason advises external image hosting with a "background:url" code line pointing to it, as used by Panos and me.]

I started with a 1400 x 1050 wallpaper of Google's logo which didn't have a mirror-reflection. (I couldn't find a good image with the bottom mirror reflection, but ever since seeing Panos' style, I wanted the mirroring. I had no idea there were so few Google logo images with a GOOD mirror reflection). The wallpaper I chose had a logo-only center detail of 1175 x 438 pixels....
  - That logo was cropped out and resized downward;
  - Its gamma & color saturation were increased to change the highlighting appearance;
  - A mirrored bottom was added (like the one I liked so much in Panos' logo. However, I didn't use a mirror
    reflection under the "g" descender. In Panos's logo, there was a descender "shadow", not a true "reflection").

  * Panos' original image:
     - http://i.imgur.com/KAfdVfw.png
  * 1400 x 1050 Wallpaper from which the new logo was taken:
     - http://userscontent2.emaze.com/images/a09fb844-1e62-4db6-804b-2c03f8ad223e/635448219895042126_googlewithblackbackground.jpg

  * R. Schneider's final edit, with color corrections, added mirroring, and resizing, for my "(Lg)" Large logo style:
     - http://s13.postimg.org/jji2zt553/gglmrrblk_476x211.png
        (inserted into Panos' code... Ctrl+F search for the string "#lga>*" (without the quotes).

* I also modified some obsolete "@-moz-document" URLs in Panos' code, as follows:
  - Removed no-longer-valid "https://encrypted.google", "http://209.85.165.104" & blogsearch entry (discontinued by
    Google);

/******  CHANGES FOR NEW LOGO (NOTES by R. SCHNEIDER) ******************************************

* The URL in "background:url" is changed to point to R. Schneider's new logo (see COMMENTS section at top). [Panos' original = http://i.imgur.com/KAfdVfw.png]

* Panos' original #lga>* code block results in ONLY APPROXIMATE CENTERING OF THE GOOGLE LOGO, AND MORE IMPORTANTLY, the logo position DRAMATICALLY AND PROGRESSIVELY DE-CENTERS with page zoom magnification. I discovered this issue with my small logo "Black Google by Panos - Mod by R. Schneider (Sm)" style, which uses Panos' code. I noticed the logo de-centering issue is the same with Panos' style and my small logo style, even though my logo size is different. After troubleshooting the Panos de-centering issue, I discovered the fix below:

 [NOTE: CSS speak: a Declaration comprises a Property and a Value, separated by a colon, i.e.,  a Declaration = some Property:some Value]

* REMOVING 3 lines of Panos' code (Declarations) - "position: absolute!important;", "top: 195px!important;"," AND "left: 40%!important;" - RESULTS IN PERFECT CENTERING OF A "LARGE" LOGO, WITH "NO" DE-CENTERING WHEN PAGE IS ZOOMED, without any further changes. ["SMALL" logos (like Panos') need an additional fix]...

* ADD the "center" Value to the "background:url" Declaration, as shown in the code below. This results in PERFECT LOGO CENTERING, WITH NO DE-CENTERING WHEN PAGE IS ZOOMED, WITH "SMALL" LOGOS. (NOTE - the "center" Value addition to the "background:url" DECLARATION is "REQUIRED" with "SMALL" logos.

* ADJUST THE VERTICAL POSITIONING OF THE GOOGLE LOGO TO SUIT YOUR PREFERENCE by modifying the "padding:_px!important;" code line. (The higher the pixel Value number, the more the logo gets "pushed down" from the top of the screen). Adjust the "px" Value to either accommodate differing height images, or different vertical positioning user preference. NOTE: ADJUSTMENT IS PROBABLY REQUIRED, EVEN FOR AN UNCHANGED LOGO, "after" first adding the "center" Value to the "background:url" Declaration.

* MAKING ALL THE CHANGES DESCRIBED ABOVE (and shown below) TO PANOS' CODE RESULTS IN PERFECT LOGO CENTERING, REGARDLESS OF PAGE ZOOM MAGNIFICATION, FOR BOTH "SMALL" AND "LARGE" LOGOS. I assume this also applies regardless of display screen pixel resolution, due to the way the "center" Value in the "background:url" Declaration works.
       
* BOTTOM LINE - With either large logos or small logos, Panos' 3 code line Declarations mentioned above (and shown below) should be REMOVED. With smaller logos, adding the "center" Value to the "background:url" Declaration is REQUIRED (see code below) - but with some large logo sizes it's NOT REQUIRED (possibly due to CSS or <div style... elements in Google's HTML). It's probably best to simply USE the "center" Value in ALL "background:url" Declarations, regardless of logo size - then, if the logo is later changed to a different size, no code adjustment would be needed... FINALLY, AFTER "center" is added to "background:url", ADJUST THE LOGO's VERTICAL POSITION by modifying the "padding:_px!important;" pixel Value number.[Adjusting it too small can result in cropping of the logo, EVEN ITS WIDTH - strange, huh?]

***********************************************************************************************/

/* LEGAL NOTICE: #lga>* code block changes below are Licensed under CC BY-NC (Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial) AND Copyright © 2015 by R. Schneider - rschneider@engineer.com (author). The following code changes to the #lga>* code block enabled, for the first time, absolute, perfect logo centering regardless of webpage zoom magnification. (With Panos' original code, the logo was only approximtely centered, and it de-centered dramatically, and progessively more, with page zoom). The following changes fixed that issue - ADDING "center" value to "background:url" declaration (it had not been used before); and REMOVAL of 3 declarations from Panos' code ("position:absolute", top:_px", and "left:_%"). The code changes can be freely copied and used AS LONG AS ATTRIBUTION IS MADE by including this LEGAL NOTICE with its attribution, above the #lga>* code block. */

#lga>* {
background: url(http://i.imgur.com/aH9C5PM.jpg)no-repeat center!important;  /* "center" added by R. Schneider to Panos' code (see CHANGES above) */
height: 0px !important;
padding:100px!important;       /* Changed from Panos' "95px" to adjust logo's vertical position - EXPERIMENT HERE TO SUIT YOUR PREFERENCE (see CHANGES text block above) */
width: 275px!important;
   /* position: absolute!important;  Removed from Panos' code to allow centering of logo by including "center" Value in "background:url" Declaration */
   /* top: 195px!important;          Removed from Panos' code to allow centering of logo by including "center" Value in "background:url" Declaration */
   /* left: 40%!important;           Removed from Panos' code to allow centering of logo by including "center" Value in "background:url" Declaration */
z-index: 1!important;
}

#lga>* * {opacity:0!important;}
div[nowrap=nowrap] {position:static!important;}
